com.jgoodies.plaf
Class FontUtils

java.lang.Object
  com.jgoodies.plaf.FontUtils
public final class FontUtils
extends java.lang.Object

Provides convenience behavior to set font defaults. Used by the JGoodies look&feel implementations.

Author:
Karsten Lentzsch

Method Detail

useSystemFontSettings

public static boolean useSystemFontSettings()
Checks and answers if we shall use system font settings. In 1.3 environments we need to guess the system fonts.

Using the fonts set by the user can potentially cause performance and compatibility issues, so allow this feature to be switched off either at runtime or programmatically

initFontDefaults

public static void initFontDefaults(javax.swing.UIDefaults table,
                                    java.lang.Object controlFont,
                                    java.lang.Object controlBoldFont,
                                    java.lang.Object fixedControlFont,
                                    java.lang.Object menuFont,
                                    java.lang.Object messageFont,
                                    java.lang.Object toolTipFont,
                                    java.lang.Object windowFont)
Sets different fonts to all known widget defaults. If the specified menuFont is null, the given defaults won't be overriden.

getMenuFont

public static java.awt.Font getMenuFont(javax.swing.UIDefaults table,
                                        FontSizeHints hints)
Computes and answers the menu font using the specified UIDefaults and FontSizeHints.

The defaults can be overriden using the system property "jgoodies.menuFont". You can set this property either by setting VM runtime arguments, e.g. 

   -Djgoodies.menuFont=Tahoma-PLAIN-11
or by setting them during the application startup process, e.g. 
   System.setProperty(Options.MENU_FONT_KEY, "dialog-BOLD-12");

getControlFont

public static java.awt.Font getControlFont(javax.swing.UIDefaults table,
                                           FontSizeHints hints)
Computes and answers the control font using the specified UIDefaults and FontSizeHints.

The defaults can be overriden using the system property "jgoodies.controlFont". You can set this property either by setting VM runtime arguments, e.g. 

   -Djgoodies.controlFont=Tahoma-PLAIN-14
or by setting them during the application startup process, e.g. 
   System.setProperty(Options.CONTROL_FONT_KEY, "Arial-ITALIC-12");

guessFont

public static java.awt.Font guessFont(int size)
Makes a good guess for the platform's system font using the specified font size. Tries to get the MS Tahoma font, that should be present on most Windows platforms; it comes with all recent Windows releases and with the MS Office.
